Award.AwardTitle: Technical Skills for Agriculture Irrigation Technicians

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As the western United States experiences continuing drought conditions, irrigation efficiency and water conservation are more critical than ever before, creating a need for irrigation technicians with state-of-the-art skills. To address this need, Modesto Junior College (MJC) will implement an Agriculture Irrigation Technology program. The project will increase the number, and improve the preparation and technical expertise of irrigation technicians and designers who are prepared to improve agriculture water management, increase irrigation delivery system efficiency, and enhance on-farm water conservation. Three specific objectives support the goal of the program: 1) Develop and deliver standardized curriculum that advances the efficient design and use of irrigation systems and can be replicated at other institutions; 2) Create a pipeline of skilled, certified technicians that meet current conservation, efficiency and water management regulations; and 3) Increase recruitment and success rates for underrepresented students in agricultural science technical programs.

Specific activities will include development of a new associate degree, an Irrigation Technology Summer Institute to increase the recruitment and retention of typically underrepresented students in this field, on-site student advising, hands-on experience with state-of-the-art technology, and industry internships. A new curriculum will combine a strong foundation in science, including critical components of plant science, soil science, hydrology, and meteorology with cutting edge technology that enables workers to accurately put water when and where it is needed. This program is contributing to the improvement of student learning and preparation in multiple agricultural science areas, and has relevance for animal science, plant and crop science, environmental horticulture, as well as other agriculture disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modesto Junior College Agriculture Irrigation Technology Program

Through the NSF ATE Program, Modesto Junior College (MJC) developed a two-year Agriculture Irrigation Technology program in response to the severe impacts on farmers and growers from the recent California drought. The program was one of the first in the nation to provide technical education for state-of-the art irrigation needs. Students learned to use advanced weather technology systems, drone images of water saturation and filtration, remote sensing and spatial technologies, GIS for evapotranspiration estimation, soil and crop drainage measurements, and computer analysis of irrigation systems. They learned system design principles as well as maintenance and repair skills.

Three specific goals informed the project:

1) Develop and deliver standardized curriculum that advances the efficient design and use of irrigation systems and can be replicated at other institutions

2) Create a pipeline of skilled, certified technicians that meet current conservation, efficiency, and water management regulations

3) Increase recruitment and success rates for underrepresented students in agricultural science technical programs

Each of the goals was met and surpassed. Curriculum was developed and shared with multiple colleges. Sixty-five students have enrolled in the program. Seven have completed the degree, with others still in the pipeline. Employers, including local irrigation districts offer internships to program students, and several have successful completed the National Irrigation Association certification. The program has attracted a high percentage of Hispanic students, who have not traditionally been interested in agriculture programs. The complex technical knowledge and computer analysis required for technicians provides a high-tech approach to agriculture careers that is different than expectations of working in the field.

New curriculum was developed and approved by the California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office, resulting in an Agriculture Irrigation Associate Degree, and four certificates: Irrigation Technology, Irrigation Management, Irrigation design, and Irrigation Construction and Installation. Curriculum and equipment requirements have been shared with colleges throughout California, Washington, and in national conferences to other colleges.

As part of the project, a state-of-the-art irrigation laboratory was constructed on land owned by the college. The lab was built in partnership with local irrigation districts, farmers, and equipment companies. Students now have a self-contained irrigation lab, complete with reservoir, pumping station, pumps, pipes, sprinklers, and computer technology that is required to replicate irrigation systems. Students now have access to current technology. Irrigation districts and farmers work closely with program principal investigators to inform the content of the program and to learn of new irrigation technologies as students become experts in new technology uses for agriculture. Local irrigation districts and other employers provide internship opportunities for students and several have been offered full-time jobs.

The Agriculture Irrigation technology program is a high-profile program for the College and in the community. Local farmers and irrigation districts are continuing to partner with MJC faculty and benefit from the knowledge and skills students are developing.
